_exec_summary.SummaryText:
In this Wastewater Treatment Plant facility, we handle Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide which is considered hazardous by EPA. The same properties that make Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide valuable as a Wastewater treatment chemical, also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide.   Over all, the prevention of unnecessary Human Exposure, reducing the threat to our own personal health as well as our co-workers, and reducing the threat to nearby members of the community is the main goal of incorporating this Risk Management Plant into our daily operations.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, with the safe handling procedures that we utilize, and the training of our personnel.



Our Emergency response program was originally deveoped in 1999 with the assistance of Environmental Data Services, inc and has since been reviewed and the emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the Mountain Home Fire Department, then the notification of the Director of Water & Wastewater Services, then notification of the Baxter County 911 System for 911 call-out to the affected population.  The Mountain Home Fire Department and Mountain Home Police Department will help to notify and evacuate any potentially affected neighbors by utilizing vehicles with PA mounted systems.  The 911 Ststem will also notify Baxter County Offices of Emergency Services. 



The primary purpose of this facility is to treat the Wastewater system by utilizing the chemicals (Chlorine & Sulfur Dioxide) for disinfection and dechlorination to the wastewater system.  Chlorine is received in by individual one ton cylinders at the 527 Hicks road location and stored until needed.  Chlorine is fed into the wastewater system by automatic feeders at the beginn

ing of chlorine contact chamber to chlorinate the treated wastewater and at the end of the chlorine contact chamber the sulfur dioxide is injected to remove the chlorine that is added before discharge to the creek.  All cylinders operate on a vacuum system.  This vacuum system will prevent the continual operation of the system is there is an increase or decrease in operating pressure on the cylinders or lines.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel, and authorized contractors.



The regulated substances handled at the 537 Hicks Road location are Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide.  The maximum amount of Chlorine on hand at any one time is 8000 lbs.  The maximim amount of Sulfur Dioxide on hand at any one time is 8000 lbs. 

2 cylinders are connected online with only 1 cylinder feeding at a time, an automatic switchover valve is connected to the system that allows the feeding cylinder to switch to the second cylinder when the first tank empties.



The worst-case scenario is failue of our largest storage tank, when filled to the greatest amount allowed, would release 2000 lbs of Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide from the chlorine storage area at 537 Hicks Road location.  It is assumed that the entire contents are released as vapor.  This location is classified as urban due to the thickly populated trees and steep hilly terrain around the site.  



The alternative scenario was determined for this facility; based upon the type of prevention system in place, the alternative release from a one ton cylinder would be unlikely for the 537 Hicks road site.  The cylinders that are connected for feeding are in a totally enclosed rooms are on a vacuum system which is determined to be effective in preventing small amounts of chlorine from excaping upon a system failure.  An estimation, if a release occurred during cylinder change-out, would be approximately 10 pounds into the atomosphere.  This amount of vapor release would result

in a distance to endpoint of less than .1 mile to to release in completely enclosed room..  



We have had no accidental releases of Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide in the last 5 years.  The Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide System was constructed in August 1998 and is in compliance with all applicable regulations for water and wastewater facilities.
